m_DescList: The regular expression (?i: subexpression) indicates that subexpression will be matched case-insensitively.
These operations are called group options. For all available optional parameters, refer to <color=#05C3BA>(?</color><color=#AB2800>imnsx-imnsx: subexpression</color><color=#05C3BA>)</color>.

For example, <color=#05C3BA>(?i: </color><color=#3173FF>[</color><color=#AB2800>abc</color><color=#3173FF>]</color><color=#05C3BA>)</color> matches the sample string <color=#3c3cff>aBC</color> with the following results:

<color=#05C3BA>(?i: </color><color=#AB2800>subexpression</color><color=#05C3BA>)</color> allows <color=#3173FF>[</color><color=#AB2800>abc</color><color=#3173FF>]</color> to match both lowercase and uppercase letters, equivalent to <color=#3173FF>[</color><color=#AB2800>abcABC</color><color=#3173FF>]</color>.
In workflow scenarios, one program may sometimes read logs output by another program and perform differentiated processing based on the log messages.
For instance, if the previous program's log contains "error", it suggests potential errors in the upstream program's execution that require attention.
Now, the goal is to match logs containing "error".
To simplify the difficulty, the following conventions are made:
1. Test cases start with a 4-digit year-2-digit month-2-digit day prefix.
2. Each test case contains only one line of logs.
Please construct a regular expression that passes all test cases on the right.
